I really wanted to like the game. The concept is cool, the cars are many and wonderful models. The controls suck, it's a super slippery racing game with sluggish unresponsive controls.

feels good, looks good, good variety of cars and overall a lot of fun.

however, I can no longer recommend the game. Right now, it's borderline unplayable. It freezes all the time and I have to close the game, and many players are having similar issues. What's worse, I just lost all of my progress today for no reason. I didn't do anything to the game except reinstall it to try and fix the freezing and now I no longer have any progress or any of my cars. I have no idea if Microsoft is responsible but they probably are given how much they neglect this game and allow it to have issues.

On top of that, the game already had a bunch of issues. Online connection is bad and online matchmaking is atrocious, one of the worst I've ever seen. frequent freezes and errors with loading in everything are common, to the point where people avoid most online match types because they expect them to bug out (and they often do).

there are various other problems but I'd have to write an essay to cover everything.

Just don't buy forza games until they make a good one and KEEP IT IN GOOD CONDITION; the new one is shit anyway.

Game is what it is, the negative review is me making sure you know that the optimisation and server calls for this game are garbage. I've had this game crash repeatedly when I made changes that needed to be saved on the server profile: a cars upgrade purchases/tuning settings, auction house interactions and livery design interactions. This makes a lot of the menuing a ticking timebomb of just wondering if the next tune setup is going to crash the game and loose you 10 minutes. Considering I managed to replicate this bug with the same car repeatedly it feels like just something the publisher isnt willing to invest time in to fix.

The always online live service stuff also leaves a bad taste in my mouth, since it means that even if you just wanna do some solo driving in the countryside you might get physics rubberbanding thanks to lagspikes which make cars undrivable whenever that happens.
Also the unskippable dlc ad cutscenes are grating.
Also also the unskippable intro gets really annoying after the 4th crash in a row.

So I guess if you're dying to play a forza game maybe youre better off playing the next entry. Its where they might maybe put their support into anyway.

I played Forza Horizon 2 on Xbox a few years ago, so it has been nice to revisit the franchise again on PC. It's a great game and I've been enjoying it so far.

I have experienced quite a few game crashes though, so bear that in mind. This is frustrating, as you always start at your house regardless of where you were or what you were doing when it closes.

EDIT: I'm coming back now after almost finishing the game completely, it's been great and I'd still definitely recommend it.

That being said, I have some more criticisms. Despite being set in Great Britain, almost every car is LHD and very few even have a number plate on the front, even sometimes when there is an obvious place for one. This is quite disappointing to see and feels a bit lazy. Another thing, online adventure is a pain to play, there is a 10 minute plus wait between races even when already in a room, also it almost never changes your rank. These issues have been known about for some time, yet there is no fix.

- Require Xbox login
- No way to organize cars, not enough
- Redundant menu clicking (auctions, messages, etc)

Look, before i start, this is a good game. cars go vroom, handling is fun, and its ultimately what ive come to expect from a non kart racing game. but there are some questionable choices that have been made as part of the fundemental design of the game that im just not sure about. wheelspins are lootboxes that while yes they give out frequently seem to have their drops tied with progression, which will eventually dry up as i play on. the ui has the feel of "this is the forth one fans, you know where the thing you want is" when im just jumping in. many features of the game seem to be heavily progression locked, (my current complaint being fast travel, but the daily objectives was the previous hurdle) 

but mostly all of this could be forgivable if i could just race against other people. ive seen them in the world, and no i know the difference between the fakes and the real deal, but there is no matchmaking or queueing system from what i can tell, you're expected to go up to an event and be able to race against others but most of the time you end up getting kicked because nobody came to race, so you end up queuing against bots, which is boring as they don't seem to have any personality to driving besides follow the line. i want drivers who actively try to fuck me not good clean racers.

oh, did i mention that since a newer title has come out in the series they've put this one into maintenance mode? no new content is fine but ive noticed my connection to online has been shittier since the release of the newer title, pointing to them changing something behind the scenes. so if you want to play a racing game start with the newer title, and avoid this one.

This game is obnoxiously flamboyant to the point it's annoying.  There's a "spin the wheel" game where you can win a bugatti veyron, but then the wheel will tick over to the next prize, a pink sweater you can dress your character in.  Whiskey Tango Foxtrot.  But at least it's not as bad as some stupid emoji dance you can make your character do when they win...oh wait, no, it is.

The clutch isn't a real clutch, it's just a button you push while selecting the gear.  If you're stopped you don't need to push in the clutch to stop the engine from stalling.  For supposedly one of the best car enthusiast games I would have appreciated a fully working clutch.  The shifting mode is determined by your difficulty level, not by the actual car, so you tend to have go through the setting when you get done driving a fully manual four speed like a 71' Dodge Charger to a 14' Dodge Charger with an slap stick 8 speed automatic.  WHISKEY TANGO FOXTROT.  I ain't got time to shift through 8 gears.  It's an automatic for a reason!

Just the whole game is obnoxious, but I've already paid for it so I guess I'll keep playing :(

So to some it up, this game is great if you want to feel like you're driving a car but you don't actually want the work behind driving a car.  And again, it's obnoxiously flamboyant.

Constant freezing with a Fanatec wheel. This game is for 12 year olds with an xbox controller. I have owned several Forza games since the first amazing release. I once drove 4 hours to get the collectors edition. Then 2 years ago, I bought Forza Horizon 4 and at the end of the first race, it froze. I spent a lot of time trouble shooting it and tracked it down to my Fanatec CS 2.5 Wheel. Apparently you have to download a 4 year old driver to use it with FH4. I submitted a trouble ticket 2 years ago and they ignored it and moved on to FH5. 

Realism: Non-existent. You can be flat out at 225 mph in your Mclaren, and a soccer mom in a dodge mini-van will cruise past you. I enjoyed cruising the roads in the UK and the graphics, but I don't know how they can make me like this game...

Car upgrade and tuning mechanics might be better balanced but enough for a arcade-y simulation, i believe. Haven't tried the Fortune Island yet but i found the LEGO DLC unnecessary, just a waste of my hard drive space, really.

This game will give you a real rush at the start, hitting you with catchy music and explosions of xp rewards for every little thing you do on the road: drive over objects, ding ding ding you just earned X out X of this! But it's one of those games that eventually becomes a job to play, because they try to trick you into playing and spending money ingame more than they try to give you good racing content. Amazingly, I quickly ran out of races, doing mostly night racing an normal racing events. After few days, I simply had no more of those, ignoring the lego-dlc, which I haven't tried. It's amazing how fast a game of this supposed scope becomes boring. I really dislike the horizon formula, imo its a completely broken progression system.

You would think that the player made races would provide some form of endgame after you've done the content you like, but 99% are just "get money fast" races, which are designed to break the AI. People do this because the game turns into a job if you want to grind for the expensive things. Really bad monetization effect.
Sense of speed is crap, but after a while of playing. (more than 30 hours). I got accustomed to it and now I'm doing well in online races~
I recommend this game and I also recommend that they should add all the Tesla's and a VW Amarok 3.0L V6.

Great racing game with a lot to do and tons of cars to collect. The game has several different types of races all over the map, as well as side events like speed zones, drifting, and business that grow in value with more challenges completed. The sheer amount of events you can participate in is impressive, and there are weekly and monthly challenges that give you new and rare cars. The two major DLCs are great, I felt like the races in those were higher quality than the base game and add new mechanics. The Lego one is especially good, it adds lego cars and a challenge system to build your house, very cool. The gameplay is halfway between a more casual experience and a racing sim, i liked how you can alter different settings to make it more casual or serious depending on what you want out of it. 

I only have a few criticisms, one being the online. The game is a few years old at this point and FH5 came out not too long ago so most of the people playing are really good and have top tier cars. It makes it hard to do well, but thankfully for most multiplayer weekly challenges you just have to finish a game, not win. The other major criticism is the base game races can get a little boring after a while. There are a lot, but since they all are based on the overworld there's not a lot of variety in scenery or unique layouts in the track. I felt the DLC races were significantly more interesting due to the more unique scenery and landscapes.

I recommend this game, as it's fairly fun and enjoyable when you get the hang of it. Though, there are tonnes of flaws on the steam version that can make it unenjoyable, and with this as well; certain aspects of the game don't turn out to be as "amazing" as others have stated.

Let's begin:

Pro's: 
You can customize any vehicle in the game to your liking, it has an amazing tuning editor, and an easy to get-into vinyl editor. I absolutely love making vinyl for cars, and tunes. Even making entirely unique tunes that suit my driving style. The many cars to choose from make it all the better, having such an extreme variety of cars makes it one of the best games out there for this option alone. 

Con's:
The physics is hit or miss, I love the game and all, but I do not have a bias toward it saying that its physics are "godly" and I don't like to be biased about things I play either. Considering I see people talk about the games physics, from actual racecar drivers all the way to regular gamers stating the physics is a bit over the top, and slidey. This actually holds a lot of merit, especially when more than 70% of all the races, during most of the seasons are either:
-Rain
-Post rain
-Hard rain
-Snow
-Ice

It doesn't help when you have so many people defending the physics saying it's "not too bad" when it actually gets frustrating after a while. This also doesn't get into the weird hitboxes, and road glitches that absolutely make the races even more frustrating. Let's actually get to that one now.

The weird hitboxes and random stopping of cars from top speed all the way to zero is infuriating, it makes it worse when almost everyone that decides to make stupid as fuck speed builds use the rally suspension. This causes more people to complain about an issue that isn't that big of an issue, unless you somehow hit a weird spot on a bridge without even touching the railing, this gets even more infuriating with the roads, where your car will somehow fly off the road because the game decided: "Nah, I don't like how you're racing" - I've experienced this more than enough times to really get me in a particularly bad mood. This, along with how weird the roads are in the circuits, from smooth, to random elevation changes. This makes the racing experience pretty annoying to deal with. Especially for newer players.

Customization:
This is both a pro and con, but this is actually about bodykits, to aero. So, the biggest thing I love to do is tune my cars to look similar to their GT varients, and you can do this for a few cars, but the lack of cars that you can do it with is a bit annoying when it comes down to uniqueness. This part doesn't bother me, but it for sure bothers other people. Hence why I mentioned it. Though, the Forza Aero is almost always the "rice special" that is, on most cars, there are some good cars without this issue. However, it's almost always the option for downforce. Which isn't the greatest thing in the world, when you have to stick it on cars that need it for better track capability. I find it ridiculous, but I can't exactly complain because I enjoy handling over top speed.

Builds:
One thing that leaves me irritated is the same-y builds that people use all the time, especially in rivals. The V12 swap, all-wheel-drive special. Gotta be honest, I get it's easy to do, but are you pulling my leg? I honestly hate "META" builds, and "META" in any game possible, so this one is purely subjective. 

Crashing/lagging:
This one is annoying as fuck to deal with, and to be honest; try every solution you find, and even reinstall the game if you have to - to see if you can get it working without these issues. I hate how it's one of the biggest problems that this game has, because the game is so fun to cruise around in, and enjoy over the summer, or whenever you feel like playing. 


Though with all that said and done, I recommend this game if you're into simcade style racing games, I love games like this as they often leave me in awe and because of the customization for vinyl and tuning, I tend to have an extreme liking to this, and I especially love how everyone can see your vinyl that you've setup on the car itself.

Pretty good semi-realistic racing game. I'm normally a fan of more arcadey stuff but this one was an exception. 

I've played Gran Turismo and Test Drive Unlimited and couldn't get into them because I hated the way the cars handled but in this game there is a pretty good balance with how they handle to heavily encourage realistic racing while also allowing you to do some risky stuff sometimes which is pretty fun. There is also well over 600 cars to drive that can all be tuned so this game is definitely not lacking in the content department (Though I do wish the open world was a bit bigger)

I think the biggest criticism I have is in regards to the multiplayer. The game is clearly built around multiplayer to the point that it can be kind of a detriment; endgame is clearly built around multiplayer and participating in the "adventures" and some of the seasonal events require other people to be participating in it as well or you just can't play them. I won't lie I'm pretty biased towards encouraging more singleplayer than multiplayer content but it would at least be nice for to be able to do these events with AI when there are no other players as opposed to just missing out on them entirely, because as a result of this design decision there are times where there is really nothing to do and the everything can feel empty as a result.

Also it would be cool to have track races, and yeah I know that 1: thats what the main Forza series is for and 2: the lego DLC has a track area, but having a handfull of track races that take place seperate from the main maps as part of a "track racing series" would be pretty cool and I don't think it would be redundant considering the Horizon series is way less focused on realism.

This game is so insanely fun. Fair warning: it's addictive - I spent nearly 24 hours of the first two days I owned it playing. The mechanics are a solid upgrade from something like Asphalt or GTA driving, but not to the point of being entirely for full-control driving sim players. It feels great to play with a keyboard, but even better on controller. The graphics are stunning and downright impressive for a nearly four-year-old game - its graphical quality even competes with games released last year. I have yet to play Horizon 5, but from what I've seen, it's even better. Don't let that deter you from buying this absolute gem though - if you can get a good discount like I did during the Summer Sale, just go for it. I will soon be trying Horizon 5, and I'm really eager to see the improvements they made.

TL:DR - Extremely fun, great mechanics, beautiful future-proof graphics, 9.5/10 overall. Buy it if you love casual driving or racing but aren't sweaty like people who play Assetto Corsa.

It's beautiful and it's absurd, and, next week, it will all be different

Amazing open world racer. Stunning visuals, great roster of cars, tons of activities to do and completionist items to fulfill, satisfying engine sounds, tight sim-cade controls, good soundtrack. This game is fun. It looks beautiful, driving feels great, and there's TONS of cars to drive and customize.

However, it has a VERY abrasive take on DLC. Don't get me wrong, there's nothing inherently wrong with DLC, and in a lot of cases it can improve your experience. But this is the only game I've ever played that forces you to watch several minute long, unskippable ads for it's DLC. If you're planning on getting it anyway, it won't bother you, but if you're like me and don't want it, it's unbelievably annoying.

One of the best racing games I've ever played! There are 4 seasons and I love them. The cars are absolutely fantastic. The multiplayer is good but sometimes it's hard to find other players when playing online.

Finally, a good racing game! The devs really put some work into this. 

For years, I've had to deal with crap racing titles that start off easy enough, but amp up the difficulty exponentially as you progress through the game to the point where it's literally impossible to win a race. Thankfully, that isn't the case here; it's challenging, but not insanely difficult. There are plenty of activities including street racing, off road racing, drifting, jumps, stunt driving, (online, LAN, or solo) and more. 

I enjoyed the environments and the extensive collection of vehicles. Great visual and mechanical customization, too.

Great game, awesome and very well-optimized graphics, dazzling to the point of being almost therapeutic, with semi-realistic but fun driving physics and mechanics that only serve to enhance my immersion in it. I've waited years to have this game arrive on steam, and when it did, it blew any expectations or preconceptions I had about racing games right out of the water. This game is so good, on so many fronts, that it is the sole reason that I'm never playing Need For Speed or the Crew series again. Game allows me to live vicariously through all the different cars and beautiful landscapes that I can drive them in. If it's on a sale, BUY IT. If it's not on sale, I'd still highly recommend getting it. It stands up well even to its direct sequel, of which I would consider an equal.

Although there will be no more future car updates this game will still remain fun as there are a lot of cars to collect and drive. There are a lot of amazing cars in the game, each one detailed and unique, but what I've enjoyed the most is driving the classic cars from the mid-50's, 60's, and 70's that were rare and exciting when I was growing up. I like to drive in the first-person point of view, behind the steering wheel, and have enjoyed the realism. I'm a PC gamer, but have been playing with an Xbox controller, and it's neat to feel the feedback in the controller as you slip off the pavement, drive down a rutted road, or over Lego studs. This is a fantastic game, and I can't believe I waited this long to play it.

This game is really good to play overall I recommend starting out with the Charger as it has decent speed. Brakes are ass though. Handling is meh. But overall if you get the supercharged preset it'll boost your speed to 223 mph and over 300 km/h. only played for 5 hours but it's a really good game if you have a decent pc you can run it on. I have the setting on ultra and the game runs real smooth and looks fucking awesome if you have a curved monitor. But overall this game is a definite buy. You will experience the 4 seasons. Summer, Autumn, Winter and Spring. Get ready and buckle up so you can race into the world of Forza Horizon 4.
It is a fun game with lots of things to do in the game and the new DLCs, you will never get bored

The game is cool an so on, but there is one HUGE flaw in it: it does not value your time.
I've played only 5 hrs but this is so annoying already. You play a 1 minute race but you MUST sit and watch a 20 sec cutscene, then watch player's showcase with cars and shit for another 10-20 sec or so, then you finally can have fun playing, after that you must wait a post-race score showcase and shit again for 10-20 seconds or so, sometimes roll for goodies. Add loading times on top of that. You end up spending half of the time just doing NOTHING! EVERY. FUCKING. RACE. YOU SIT AND DO NOTHING HALF OF THE TIME.

Dear Microsoft, give us at least an OPTION to skip, because this is just ridiculous.

Unskippable cutscenes and cringy dialog. I just wanted to drive some cars around a big map. GTA with more cars. This game fails at all the little things. You have to be signed into a microsoft account, you have to watch every single cutscene no skipping (and if you mess up you get to watch it again), If your whole thing is just wanting to drive around some cars you still have to play through what I'm assuming is the story first. Didnt bother even trying to get through it. and looking over the less than user friendly UI it's fairly apparent this was set up to be a pay to win game.

TL;DR Wanna drive cool cars around with no extra fuss? Don't get this game.

This is an amazing deal right now. You get a great game, plenty of cars & other bonuses right after you complete the tutorial for 1/3 of the regular price. This game is a must have, either you like or don't like racing games because this game is not just another racing game it has a little bit of The Sims vibes to it. Forza Horizon 4 is very friendly to newcomers, has a stunning visuals and sound design, tons of cars, pretty big community and 100+ hours of content. It is also a great therapy game so you can just turn off your brain and drive around UK in your favorite car to some music and simply relax. Highly recommend.

After being in a gaming slump for the past year or so, so I deliberated between 4 and 5, and, after some thinking, I grabbed this, thinking it'd be a fun time (cheaper, more content atm, but the environment is what tipped it for sure for me.)

After just a couple minutes, I was already having such a fun time. Genuinely the best racing game I've played, and such a joy, with so much content to sink my teeth into and so much to do, and the world is absolutely gorgeous. I've found myself laughing and viscerally reacting at the amount of sheer fun I'm having doing shit in this game.

I'll definitely be grabbing 5 eventually, but this game is incredible and has easily made me a Horizon lover.

[h1] Standard Racing game done right[/h1]

Forza 4 sets a standard for racing games in my opinion. 
Forward, backwards and drifting with automatic gears.

The graphics are beautiful and so are the cars.
The game is fun with a good variety of activities to do.
 
The game sadly has a gambling mechanic with a wheel of fortune type of thing.
The game has a hidden or obvious difficulty in some races, by that, I mean slower cars generally make a race a lot easier than with fast cars. This is in addition to how you normally would choose a difficulty.
The game also needs you to make an Xbox account, but it doesn't require a separate launcher.

The game should have music that most people enjoy with a handful of varied radio stations.
And you can a lot of customisation which I personally really enjoys.

Overall a very good experience with a few minor hiccups 8.5 out of 10 from me.
A gorgeous, rewarding, and self-renewing driving experience that raises the open-world racing bar yet again.

Before I start this review, I have 65 hours on my Xbox through Xbox Game Pass and have beat the game there.

This game is a must-buy during any sort of sale because the developers have finished working on it, meaning that all the expansions and DLC cars are out and provide lots more content that Forza Horizon 5, which is still pending a 2nd expansion and the 1st one being released soon. The storyline is okay, it's nothing too special. Showcase events are infuriating because your opponent (train, air mattress thing) always have the direct line to the finish while you are required to make twists and turns, although it's still possible to beat them.  This game provides a lot of incentives to keep playing, like the daily forzathon challenges, which I just do without even looking at them. You also get random gifts in your message center, where they send you stuff along the lines of free cars, cash, or wheelspins. I think that it's a game of all time.

probably one of the best racing franchises i have ever had the luxury to play, for anyone that has ever played a horizon game you already know they are packed with tons of stuff to enjoy. the online is still pretty much alive in horizon 4 and you can easily take part in forzathon and other events.

for anyone that hasn't played one before:
- smash, find and collect signs and explore the roads in a large open world map.
- test your limits with speed zones, drifts, jumps & pr stunts.
- compete in various events.
- race online with PvP.
- collect luxury and rare cars.

few things to take into consideration, this one is based on England so you drive on the other side of the road, been from the UK doesn't bother me but if you are coming from horizon 2 to 4 you might need to adapt.

so based on playing all of the horizon games, i can honestly say you will not be "completing" this game in a hurry, i still have achievements unfinished on the previous titles (with the exception of the fast and furious version that i managed to 100%).

ALLRIGHT, FOR PEOPLE CONSIDERING FH4 OR FH5, I HAVE PURCHASED BOTH AND THINK FH4 IS BETTER HANDS DOWN 

so now with less yelling.
I am a reasonably newer racing game player. Love em but never got into them all too much. Typically only downloaded what came free from subscription services etc.

I purchased FH5 first and LOVED IT. Didn't realize racing games had come far enough with customization, paint editing, sound and graphics. Had never played a Horizon game and bought it on a whim wanting to see what the buzz was about.

Fast forward 100 hours later, and I can say that I love FH5. But thats not what this review is about. 
Forza Horizon 4 is just a better game, and I can comfortably say this after my first 10 hours (of presumably 100+ in the future). 

What's better? (I got both Ultimates-worth of content)

Seasons/Weather: UK has actually dynamic weather. Snow, wet, dry. The temperatures in each season adjustment. Super cool thing that makes me do more than make 1-2 cars that drive all my races. Experimenting with new things feels warranted for some points over kitting my car out for each season, but thats me.

Events/Characters/Story: I thought FH5 was boring af, and super awkward with forced social interactions. I feel like with 4 they genuinely tried to write something and I appreciate it.

Cars: As of now, I think I like the cars from 4 better. More weird brands and cool rally vehicles. Don't notice a huge difference other than a large hole where Toyota/Lexus should be (yes theres some Toyotas but you gotta go buy at auction or wait for seasonal events, base roster literally has 1 supra LOL) thats my toyota bias though.

Map: HOLY SHIT UK is more fun to drive. It feels lived in and a lot more real. I mess up driving on the wrong side often, but these roads feel sensible. Without touching DLC I think the main map works better too because you work up each competition and unlock more stuff as you go. 

UI: The User Interface/Menus on this game have character and are jammed up at times with too much info, but coming from FH5 to this game, I understand what its all for and think its better that I know where to look for it. 

Driving feel: The cars suspension feel is just much better and feels responsive to choices I make within tuning.

Until FH5 gets more content and fills their giant map with actual things to do with a sense of progression (much like this game did) I think this game is the much better choice, and will probably always be cheaper.

I've always been a fan of racing games but I had never tried RacingSim type of games. All the racing games I played were arcade games which are fun but you don't get the variety of cars and the experience you get here. 

Coming to the game, the game has a LOT of things to do, you will never be bored. I really like the fact that it doesn't have a progrssions system when you have to complete certain races to  move along the story line, as in Arcade games. I like dirt races so i can keep doing it and the game will throw more such races, which is amazing.

Cars:
Variety of cars, is just amazing. There are over 700 cars, most of which can be bought using credits from the Autoshop, but a lot of them are really rare and crazy expensive. You can still find them on the Aution House, but be sure to store a lot of credits. 

Gameplay:
Driving experience is very different. I couldn't try driving with a controller, but even the keyboard experience is not that bad. However if you can afford a controller get one. Highly recommended

DLC/PaidContent:
Coming to the DLCs, get the Ultimate Edition, Period! And buy the Hot Wheels Pack if you need it. And yes, wait for sale, it goes for around 67% discount on Sale. 

Community/OnlineContet:
The community is helpful, and there are a ton of resources online if you get stuck. I found the reddit sub the best. The game has stopped getting any new content but the online multiplayer and weekly contests will keep on coming for years, it's not going away anytime soon. Also if you plan on buying it get it before it is delisted from Steam/Windows Store because once that happends it's impossible to get it. 

Performance/Bugs/crashes: the game is surprisingly very well optimised, which is rare these days. Bugs are very rare, and although the game won't receive any new content the devs still fix minor bugs which is a good thing considering FH5 has been around for a while.
This is a very good game as long as you have something that can handle it. But other than that its a very good game. recommend it for every one.

Lots of cars, the game is freeroam, awesome soundtrack, just plain awesome. As a quick introduction to the game, Forza Motorsport is the original series of Forza games. The Motorsport series is based around closed circuit racing ie: racing at a race track. Forza Motorsport is essentially Xbox/Microsoft's equivalent to Playstation/Sony's sim racer, the Gran Turismo series. The only difference is, Forza then made the Horizon series. Horizon is open world and simcade, this to me is a major plus. Gran Turismo currently as far as I'm aware, does not have an open world experience like this.

The general premise of Horizon is that there is a festival called the Horizon Festival that is set in some part of the world, to celebrate car culture. Horizon 4 takes place in a fictionalized UK, borrowing some real world locations/landmarks, and just mashing it all into one island.

The biggest plus with Horizon 4 is that it has all proper 4 seasons unlike you weirdos who live near the equator and don't experience snowy winters. Unlike Horizon 5 which takes place in Mexico, Horizon 4 has summer which is what you'd expect from summer, spring which is nice green scenery with loads of rain (typical UK?), autumn which is more rain, less green, more yellow and leaves, and finally...winter. Actual snow. Something that I never thought of as rare because I live in Canada, but to some of you who live in parts of the world with no snow, well....welcome to actual winter. Sadly it is the least active season because apparently all of you are scared of a little bit of snow, but this is currently the only Horizon game with all four seasons. Winter in Horizon 5 is NOT winter. If there is no snow, it is not winter. Simple. Sorry, not sorry. Every week is a season change, with that comes new (at this point its recycled) content. If only winter lasted for 7 days...unlike the miserable Canadian winters.

Overall the gameplay is fine, you can tune the difficulty to your liking against the Drivatars (AI racers using player names) which only affects how much money you earn so you don't always have to feel frustrated with Unbeatable Drivatars especially since the AI is notorious for defying physics despite driving lesser or seemingly equivalent cars than yours. My favourite is online. When in freeroam online, all players are ghosted, this way you can't be griefed while freeroaming unless you convoy up with friends or invite people to it. However that only applies to Freeroam (solo Freeroam specifically) or Forzathon Lives. Collision is turned on when you actually do races and events or as mentioned above with a convoy.

I mentioned Forzathon Live, what is that? Honestly one of my favourite things in this game. Every day, every hour, there is a Forzathon Live, every 50 minutes, a giant pink circle is placed on your map, you and all the people who want to participate, drive to the circle, after 10 minutes, Forzathon Live begins, you and all the players now drive to an area, and as a team, complete a common goal. For example, try and get a total speed of 10,000mph. How does this work? Well, there is a speed camera here, drive by it as fast as you can, you and all the participants need to do this until you reach 10,000mph. It sounds tough at first but with enough people and the right cars and strategy, its easy and fun. Meet new people, see cool cars, have fun driving in a non-competitive environment just doing car stuff. You do three rounds of this, and when you finish, you all get Forzathon points. 10, 20, 30 depending on how many rounds you manage to complete with the team, you get 20, 40, or 60 points if you have a specific house or VIP (which gives this house to you for free). These points can be used to buy rare cars in the Forzathon shop amongst other things. Always fun to do, non-competitive so you don't need to deal with sweaty tryhards, just have fun with the team, then you can resume with whatever you were doing before.

Overall this is a great game, yes there are known issues with the game like not being able to get 100% seasonal completion amongst other things unfortunately, no game is perfect, but compared to Horizon 5, this game is still very good. Remember, Horizon 5 takes place in Mexico, the winter in that game is not 1 winter, there is no snow. Also the car list is slightly different, some cars in this game, aren't in Horizon 5 so this is important to note. Overall I would say its a solid 8.5/10 for me. I don't feel like writing anymore since I normally write long ass reviews anyways. If you're wondering which edition to buy, personally I recommend Ultimate, it includes ALMOST all DLCs. The only things you miss are the Hot Wheels car pack (you need it in order to buy those cars in-game, but they can be driven in custom made challenge cards), Treasure Map (unlocks all map stuff, not really important), and I think the Mitsubishi pack which is free. There is also two additional Free DLCs but they're hard to find unfortunately (check or ask in Steam discussions). Either way I would recommend Ultimate for all the DLCs as you CAN'T buy the DLC cars from the Autoshow, and apparently not even the auction house unless you own said DLCs.

Final Note: Since the licensing for some of the cars in this game are almost expired, unfortunately this game will be delisted from Steam at some point, when, I don't know as its still unconfirmed and its also the first Forza game on Steam. This could be your last chance to experience Horizon 4 and what it has to offer before its gone and you only have Horizon 5 which won't have a 1 winter experience amongst other things that Horizon 4 has, so if you see it on sale, grab Ultimate Edition if you can.

Crossing the horizon "crossing the horizon" adopts the form of literary essays to comprehensively reflect Li Siguang's academic and moral qualities and elegant cultural and artistic qualities.

The book has selected his academic, interesting and readable works, essays and art talks from different periods to provide a collection for the readers. Lisiguang is a famous geologist in China and the founder of geomechanics.

He devoted his life to the research and teaching of paleontology, glaciology and Geomechanics, and wrote a large number of geological works. Crossing the horizon is one of his masterpieces.

The book strives to change a new perspective, using the form of literary essays to comprehensively reflect Li Siguang's academic and moral qualities and elegant cultural and artistic qualities.

To be honest this is one of my most favourite racing games of all time. After playing it a little on Game Pass on Xbox One I adored the choice of British landscapes and locations over the "samey" looks of American landscapes and locations. It felt very special and would remain in my memories for a long long while. I would then switch over to PS4 and then PS5 as my console of choice console. But still remembering the joys I had of this game. Then after losing access to the Xbox One and getting into PC gaming I made sure straight away to add Forza Horizon 4 to my wishlist so I could enjoy it once again. And then the day came that the game dropped massively in price I was quick to pounce on the Ultimate Edition of the game to snag all the small and big things that I had enjoyed on Game Pass years ago. So personally if you're in the market for a fun and enjoyable racing expience that can be as easy or as hard as you wish it to be, then I recommend giving Forza Horizon 4 a look at.

I'm a casual, not a hardcore racer. Every so often I like to let off a bit of steam and hopefully win a race. This was my first exposure to Forza and I was pleased. There's a lot of variety in cars and race events. You don't need to be PC Racer to get accomplishments and make progress. If you lose a few races, it downgrades the competition a bit until you find your feet and then builds up the difficulty again. The rewind feature is great for when you make a little mistake on an otherwise great race. Just rewind a little and start the section again.  I like the online community presence. It makes it feel like you might be playing against real people, even though I think the drivatars in solo mode are AI. You need an Xbox account but if you have a Microsoft account, then you already have this.

Overall, this is a fun racing game to dip in and out of and make progress through without feeling like you've got to give it blood, sweat and tears.

Almost un-recommend, refund, and buying a gamepass soon when i got an XBOX Series S or a better PC due to technical difficulties, but i managed to make it work in less than an hour.
Buying this in 10 dollar mark makes me regret or made up that last year i purchased The Crew 2 in belief that The Crew 2 ran better on my PC due to its lesser graphics.
However...
This game is miles better in ways to treat the players right.
First, in comparison to The Crew 2 (- indicate cons, + indicate plus):
-Not being set in the USA, clearly which one has the larger world?
-No controllable bikes and planes. There is only minimal number of off-road.
-Far less amount of character customization, locked behind the spinwheel, which, even if doesn't consume money, still takes a long time to progress.
+So many cars that doesn't get locked into a (real money) paywall or lengthy grindwall. 
+Increased modes of accessibility
+A navigator that actually helps instead of condescendingly repeating the same advice
+No nagging, annoying, or condescending characters. So much that you might forget they're existed if you beaten all the events.
+Better handling, though that cars handle differently is something you need to get used to.
+More ways to customize your car
+You can change your character avatar (though like The Crew 2, it's preset only) even after the game in progress 
+ You can play offline after registering for the first time.
+Microtransactions only come in packs and the ultimate edition is pretty cheap, like, 10 dollars during sale (Regional Pricing Apply)
+Little to no stutters, though the framerate in average is lower (i'm running in a potato)
+Ability to blueprint and customize events, i.e. create your own events. Something that The Crew 2 conspicuously lacks.
+Better graphics and Playground listens (such as there is no "paint splatter" or "milk spill" snow)
+Season did not transition abruptly and instantly, but throughout story and (supposedly, after you beat the first year Horizon level up missions) weekly.

Now for a real review, i can say that for the almost-100 hours i play (the first half hours is when it doesn't work) the game: 
+Doesn't crash too much (though random i can play 6+hours with no CTD but sometimes 1-2 hours and its CTD) and only stutters very minimally on me. (and this is me running on potato)
+Coming from somebody who played a lot of Need for Speed games, the car handling of Forza Horizon 4 is the BEST. For all these years apart from GTA there's Forza Horizon 4 in terms of satisfying handling (and i have played games like GRID and Ridge Racer mind you)
+Very minimal rubber-banding. So if you just lost then tweak the difficulty or car tuning or get good.
+Route Creator, which allow you to play and earn by your creativity. However....
-With the exception of the one-car Super7 events, you can't create barriers and objects like crowd viewing benches that are exclusive to Horizon-made events. EventLab in the 5th Forza Horizon is said to adding those, but i haven't played Forza Horizon 5.
-Lack of interior mods, like how to get rid unused seats because you never sit with others.
-Try NOT to use Assist once you acquire decent winning streaks. As the steering and braking might screw your ability to take advantage of shortcuts and off road passes. Later on you'll need to turn off Stability and Traction control and learn to control spins in order to either drift effectively or maximize your car's ability.
-You might (initially) need to use assists on "Showcase" (boss "battles") events given that it isn't car-against-car racing duels. Later when there's a "remix", assists could hinder you from using the full potential of your car.
-Night as it turns out, far faster than it should be only around 3-5 minutes (the polar opposite of the also Microsoft-published State of Decay games). You can mitigate it by setting up night racing events.


9/10, can recommend. Thank you Playground Games and XBOX Games Studios.

Fun to play, what else can I say about it?
Well, a few things:
1) Runs almost perfectly on Debian Testing using an AMD RX580 8GB GPU over a PCIe 3 x16 link. Force the use of Proton 7 and it should run fine.
2) Full controller support works fine. Pair up that old Xbox controller and have some fun.
3) Runs pretty well from a spinning hard disk. (2TB WD Black 2003FZEX for reference). SSD recommended for best results, as well as *AT LEAST* 32GB of DDR3-2400 RAM running in dual-channel mode. Any less RAM and you risk running out of memory whilst loading or playing the game. Any slower and you'll have stuttery gameplay. Also pair it up with an i7-4790K or better as to avoid bottlenecking the hardware. And I shouldn't have to mention this, but make sure that the SSD that your Steam library lives on is indeed a SATA III 6Gbps SSD and is connected to a SATA III 6Gbps port on your motherboard.
4) I can't think of anything else to say. Go buy the game and play it!

It's a casual, open world, seasonal, arcadey car game... where you can cut straight through gps-routes in plenty of races and immediately bounce(literally without crashing/dying) to the finish line like an absolute clown. The cars are nice though.

I'd get this only to collect and maybe make rudimentary tuning setups to cars. You make credits very fast and you'll even earn cars through roulette spins (lootboxes after every good race). It sounds cheap, but you also get 20+ gifted nice cars once the open world opens up to you. Sell them if you want if you want to save for a Ferrari, Pagani, Koenigsegg, Maserati, or whatever 1 million + dollar dream vehicle you'd like to drive.

In the first day or so when I started, I found the auction house where you can buy cars and almost immediately earned enough for a 2002 Corvette, 2006 Corvette, a Mustang, Toyota Supra, Plymouth GTO, An old Beetle, A Dodge Viper, and a Porsche. Now... I don't know about anyone else, but when I was young I had to unlock these vehicles at later vehicle stages in older racing games (PGR2) and I felt set here. I don't care about the grind right now, cause I have all my old dream cars and nice cars are just raining down on me since this game is so dang easy. Yeah, I'm on my controller and I'd rather play this in a sim mode with a wheel and pedal... but cruising is still fun with just a controller.

Anyways, PC-M&K-lover or not, plug in that plug-n-play xbox one controller and enjoy having supercars rain down on you as you earn them in the dream cars of your childhood. Horizon 4 is casual arcade fun where its just nice to look at (and yes a w&p system is a 1000% better on this. I've seen the videos of the ffeedback. A good wheel is all I need for this to be perfect).

Are there shortcomings? Yes- but any game is going to have them. The worst part is that the game isn't bigger, but there's lots to do. It is frustrating when you get forced into doing things, and there are multiple times the game pulls you away from what you're doing to force you into something else. It's annoying, but the overall driving experience and customization options compensate enough to make the gameplay good. Plus the variety of cars is nice, spanning a wide range of years, makes and models to keep it from getting stale too quickly.

Used to be one of my favorite games. Now it crashes on launch every single time.

I think it is time to vent my fustration. 

Pro:
Hands down, this is a really fantastic game when it runs. It is interesting, it is enjoyable, it just offers a lot of fun. Hard to see what can not be liked on this title.

Con:
The game starts up well till you can press enter to load the game itself. However I can't get through that point anymore. 
In the beginning worked on hours to figure out how to run the game, after it was running finally and I was happy. Played around 12 hours or even more. Then again, the game no longer wants to run, spent hours time to time when I had patience and time, but no luck. Not to mention the "what to do if your game crashes" actually asks you to stop and kill every possible app (logitech, sonic studio, and so on), windows and 3rd party firewall, antivirus. I've even opened all port I could find on internet related this game. 
 Bought a great game, but I feel cheated. Having a high end pc and not able to run a game which I bought.
I would highly recomment to check out the newest Forza, maybe that has half of this issues. This feels like a russian rulette. It is either runs well or you just spend hours and hours to figure out what else you could try to run the game.
UPDATE arrived to game, checking several way if finally it runs again... but no luck for me. Hope it might help for others... (2022.06.09.)

A great example of an open-world driving game.

Vehicle selection has plenty of variance, from modern hyper cars to racing semi trucks and plenty in between, Whether or not you like dodging traffic in street races, hitting the dirt in rally races, forgoing roads entirely in cross-country jaunts or quarter-mile drag racing, there's plenty for you to do.

Visual parts customization is limited per-car, but the livery customization is very in-depth and you can really go to town with it. You can even share your created liveries (with some limitations) with other players, and you are even rewarded in-game if your creations are used by other players.

Difficulty is more-or-less up to the player, with rewards tied in so that the harder the player makes the game, the more money they earn from events.

The game is very stable and runs well (I have experienced a few CTDs, but they were almost certainly due to the fact that my graphics card is the only aspect of my rig that doesn't meet the Recommended Specs)
it is good for kids that like cars and action. i give it a 5 star rating

4/5, Its a great game but I don't see much point into investing so much right now, especially considering Forza Horizon 5 is out. It has an active community and stuff, but they really throw a lot of the fancy cars out as soon as you start playing, which kind of ruins the whole idea of "earning" the cars you want to have. I'm not sure if this is a common thing or not, this is my first Forza game after all, but it felt like there was stuff going on and im not a part of it. A lack of linear progression or a contained storyline is what you're getting here, and if its your thing, you'll love it.

This game is the perfect blend of arcade and simulation racing. The driving is responsive and thrilling, but not to the detriment of having casual fun with the game. The tuning features really let you customize your car and make each one feel different to drive. There is a smorgasbord of content to experience and challenges ranging from babyâ€™s first race to hair pulling. There are some occasional crashes and other annoyances, but these are well compensated for by the beauty and depth of the exploitable game world. Overall, the best racing game I have yet played.
An awsome game! (Can I please have my family back now please?)

It's the best of both worlds, and the best Forza Horizon 4 has ever looked. (And it was already quite a looker.) In 4K, every detail looks sharp, from the stone walls you'll bust through every time you take a bad angle on a turn to the dials on your car's dash when you take a tour of the interior in your garage. At 60 frames per second, the more fluid animation intensifies the sense of speed that builds when you shift into high gear, whether you're gracefully drifting around sharp turns on Edinburgh's streets or launching off a ramp in the English countryside. The Xbox One X gave us a glimpse of next-gen gaming by allowing us to choose between these two technical advancements, but the Series X gives us the complete picture by combining them to make games that are incredibly detailed and smooth.

Arcade racing with beautiful graphics. Now if you're wondering to buy this one or the newest. Either one will do. This has dozen of cars to buy/earn and upgrading. There's a ton on content that can last you weeks. It's even better if you can grab friends and drive in the Open World together. Multiple race tracks with different conditions. As an avid NFS player, this game was my foray into the sorta arcade/sim hybrid that is Forza. Lacking some of the customization that the NFS series has, Forza makes up with its sheer amount of cars. This is also one of, if not the, most beautiful games I have ever played. Cars feel good to drive (when you have them spec'd into grip and have stability turned on). All this said, there is plenty to do in this game, but it does get stale after awhile. I am 50 hours in, I have cleared all the actual races, but have barely touched the "story" missions. I find them just... Kinda boring? I have certainly got my moneys worth from this game, but I couldn't recommend buying at full price. Also, unless you are just a completionist or a fan of a certain car, none of the dlc is worth buying aside from the map add-on.

I've been playing racing games all my life and this is the first Forza game I've ever played. I wish I'd got into the franchise sooner because this quickly became one of my favorite games of all time. The amount of cars there are is insane alone. But the amount of content is unlike any other racing game I've played. There's a nice variety of different types of races, and there's tons of activities, challenges, games, and stories to play throughout the map. There's also a festival playlist each week which is always fun to go through and complete to win prizes. I ended up buying the Lego Speed Champions DLC and Fortune Island DLC, and they're both great add-ons. This is an incredible game with endless replayability!

This game does not work very well on a high end game PC.  It is mostly designed for Xbox/tv use with a game controller. I used to play racing games quite a bit but stopped when the genre started taking itself far too seriously. Other people have their own views but I can't be bothered having to go through a vast tutorial to learn about breaking points, apexes, brake balance and everything else. I want a game where I can have some fun.

Forza Horizon 4 does exactly what I want. You can pretty much jump in a car and start racing. But it also does the other stuff. If you want to be able to barrel-roll your car three times and still be able to carry on racing, it will do that. On the other hand, if you want your car to be undriveable after a few fairly minor knocks, it can do that too. You can tweak your balance, brakes, gears and god knows what else, or you can leave everything on the defaults. You can race against AI that never makes a mistake or you can pick opponents that seem to struggle with all the different peddles.

I'm sure there will be those for whom the slightly madcap elements in the game will be a put-off, but for me it's simple fun and I love it.

Proâ€™s
    â€¢ Overwhelming selection of cars to choose from; your childhood favourites are most likely there
    â€¢ Graphically gorgeous
    â€¢ Very good optimisation
    â€¢ Stacks of things to do
    â€¢ Very customisable races
    â€¢ Cars have a tremendous level of customisation available
    â€¢ The map is sufficiently-sized, and enjoyable to explore
    â€¢ Has a unique rewind system; allowing you to immediately tackle a corner again without having to start the race from scratch
    â€¢ Very good level of difficulty customisation

Conâ€™s
    â€¢ AI behaviour in racing is on-rails. AI choses whether it obeys the laws of physics depending on what position you are and at what point in the race. Makes racing... uncomfortable.
    â€¢ Game launches advertising clips in-game, and forces you to sit through them on first view.
    â€¢ The dialogue is pretty terrible, unless you love your ego being stroked. It happens a LOT, and you canâ€™t skip it.
    â€¢ The only character customisations available are clothing and poses, all of which you can acquire only per chance through the Wheel Spin system, or of course in-game purchases. You end up stuck with a character that is unlikely to represent you.
    â€¢ Slot-machine style of rewards (that happen frequently).
    â€¢ Many of the rewards are things you probably donâ€™t want; like poses for your character you will never use, cars youâ€™ll never drive, and clothing youâ€™d rather burn
    â€¢ Not without bugs
    â€¢ The audio level cap is pretty low
    â€¢ You canâ€™t mute the in-game music
    â€¢ Game was not designed with H-shifting manual drivers in mind. It works, but you canâ€™t stall the car, rev the engine in neutral, and the engine revs if youâ€™re coasting downhill in neutral

The game mechanics are very good; much improved over the previous installment, I'd say. Tuning works realistically, and the courses are good... There is decent customization of your vehicles and there are tonnes of great cars to choose from. There is also a great auction menu that allows you to unload unwanted cars and pick up new cars for great prices. Practically every other aspect of the game is shite. The characters are shallow, the jokes are lame, the events are meaningless and often downright stupid. (The race against a fighter jet comes to mind) The game is constantly trying to shove paid content down your throat and there's too much focus on non-car related elements like victory dances and clothing for your avatar, all of which I could happily do without, There's a bit of douchyness, which seems to plague driving games now-a-days mainly centred around avatars, although nowhere near the amount of douchyness of a modern Need for Speed title. I, like many other Windows users am also experiencing regular crashes every hour or two. Menu music cannot be turned off or down, and in game music can only be turned off completely by selecting "no radio" in the radio menu... Another thing I could do without.

I must reveal that first, I tested this game from an unofficial release from somewhere over the rainbow, I always test games this way to see how well they perform on my hardware, then if the performance is there and I like the game, I add it to my steam wishlist and wait for a sale, then I grab it, this wasn't the first Forza I played, but the last one was quite an old one, I last played this game franchise on my X360, my console came with Forza Motorsports 2 in its bundle and I got hooked to it right away, till my X360 decided to die with the infamous RROD (the good old days). Back to the reason I didn't get any other Forza, is they were exclusive to Xbox consoles and I never replaced my X360 due to some tight budget issues at the time, or they weren't on steam, as simple as that, I don't want to have multiple games on different platforms, except for some very special cases from one I won't name here.

Ok, I only played 5hrs on this one and I love it to the max, except when it does CTD without any explanations, even in middle of a race or anywhere on the map, its just bam, back to desktop, all my drivers are up to date, everything should be fine. But I'll keep playing, I love old cars, I must be the only one that drives the old stuff and not the fastest cars of the game, I love classic cars and there's a lot of them in that game, for sure they won't win many races, but the fun is to drive them around.

Forza Horizon 4 is a fun driving simulator very similar to Forza Motorsport, with one exception. Instead of tracks, you drive on countryside roads, city streets and even sandy beaches! The Horizon Festival requires the best drivers from all over the world to participate, and you are one of them! With some very cool features such as Drivatars, scalable difficulties and some great radio stations, this game is an absolute treat!
There isn't really a story with these Horizon games, other than its a festival where competing in and winning races gains you infamy and money which allows you to participate in more races and buy cooler stuff. With The Festival going to the USA, Italy/France and Australia, its time the festival visited the UK! The map, while not to scale, includes some of the iconic British landscapes, such as the lake district, the moor and Edinburgh! Its amazing how much detail each village has, and the development team clearly put in a lot of effort to get it all right!
The main changes from previous games is that drivers now actually appear live in your game. In previous games you could create a convoy which consisted of AI Drivatars, as you would never really share an instance with other players - it was mostly offline. Another change is to skills. Instead of now collecting skills for your progress overall and shared them across cars, you now have to build up skills for each car. Skills have been made much easier to earn though.
The music is also really well crafted into the game, with each race playing a fitting looping track for the duration of the race. New and well established artists are featured on every radio station.
Overall, Forza Horizon 4 is a lot of fun and allows for some crazy stunts, but that's what this game is for! It really is a one of a kind genre, but requires some time to get into, as the tutorials and beginning just take so long. The new Horizon Stories feature were amazing, and even allows you to learn something about British automotive History... and earn some credits along the way!
Forza Horizon 4 gets an 8/10.

â­â­â­â­â­ 5/5
One of the best racing game. There's a lot to do including weekly events, stories, and speed/drift/stunt challenges. Definitely recommended.
[hr][/hr]
[b] CARS:  [/b] 
- lots of cars to choose from. iirc, it's 475 unique cars excluding DLC one.
- whole lot of community-crafted tune. so even if you're bad at tuning, you can just use one of the well-crafted build.
- tons of decals. You can also use decals made by other user as well.

[b] GAMEPLAY:  [/b] 
- visual driving line. they'll guide you on where you should be driving and when you should brake. 
- rewind system. made a mistake? hit a tree? use rewind! it'll take you back a few second so you can get another attempt at it.
- bots are not too stubborn and can't be beaten too easily. but you can adjust the difficulty from "unbeatable"(not really) to completely new-racer difficulty.
- arcade/realistic control. it has a great mix between these two. of course you can turn on full simulator mode too. drifting is not too bad as well, though you might take a while to get used to it.
- auction house.
- pretty big open-world. and the areas are not bland/empty as well.

[b] CONTENT:  [/b] 
- weekly event. win it and earn another rare car or clothing.
- stunt challenge. they're all around the map. including speed zone, speed cam, drifting zone, and 'jumping cliff'.
- stories. The game has stories for each NPC, and they excel at different stuff. Some are about drifting. some are about speeed. and some are about the classic cars. this really add up to your playtime.
- player-made challenges.
- the communities are not dying. even though forza horizon 5 is out, there's still a lot of people playing this daily.

[b] THE CONS:  [/b]   
- terrible save system. the game has an autosave system, but not a good one. I guess it works fine if you have high-end PC. but if you don't, your game might freeze while saving. and when you restart, pray that your progress is still there. You won't lose your save though, that's for sure.
- require a pretty good PC and internet.

Personally I think FH4 has way better reward system than FH5 in a sense that you don't have to grind as much to get a new car (since cars are easier to obtain in wheelspin). Somehow making the reward system works that way doesn't make the game becoming more boring due to the fact that you're gonna be able to try cars that you wouldn't even consider buying from the shop directly, not to mention the weekly forzathon challanges also rewards you with cars rather than what the FH5 gives which is an in-game currency. Overall both game have amazing graphic and great feeling when you're driving, but for the rewards system alone I would recommend FH4 more than FH5

Great game - many caveats if played on Linux

The good:
 - Very fun driving mechanics
 - Open world
 - Beautiful graphics
 - Good voice narration
 - Great variety of music
 - Excellent performance, even with Proton overhead

The not-so-good:
 - Many, *many* crashes on Linux. If you play this with proton, be sure to:
    - Set any dynamic optimization off
    - Keep controllers disconnected until you are in the world
    - Accept that crashing is still inevitable and it's a miracle that it works on Linux in the first place.
 - Required Microsoft account which will eventually be suspended if you do not 2FA
 - AI can be ridiculously easy or ridiculously difficult on the same level depending on conditions
 - I wouldn't purchase it if it weren't on a sale. I count DLC as part of the game. Are you kidding me? $100 for the ultimate edition? Same issues with FH5.

Final thoughts:
For never intended on being ran on Linux with Proton, performance is surprisingly decent. It's a great open-world arcade racing game. If you want to have a relaxing cruise on the freeway or fight your way to the top in races, this game has you covered. If you buy it on the occasional sale, it is a bargain. Just beware the Microsoft account lock. You will be unable to play the game *at all* if you don't have one.

I'm a Forza fan since the original XBOX instalment way back when, but due to life and time I really haven't played any of the modern games much. I saw this on sale and bought it to see what the new titles are like. All I can say is 'wow!' - if you're a racing fan at all this is the game for you.

The thing that appealed to me in the originals was the track / circuit progression and realistic physics and modification systems. These things are all still here, except instead of navigating through a menu for your tracks you're driving to them in the English countryside. Seasons change week-to-week and the landscape and tracks reflect this - winter is a challenge as there's knee-deep snow most places so not the best time to go and try to set speed records... although it makes for very fun offroad races.

The actual game introduction (first 5 hours or so) is a little bit painful with lots of cutscenes and adds for the DLC's, but they go away eventually. At no time do you feel like you don't know what to do which is a bonus. The menu and mapping systems are good and you can navigate 'GPS style' to a destination, event, challenge etc.

There are a heap of ways to play this game. I got used to the landscape by doing Speed Camera and Jump challenges, which are just areas on the map where you go fast to break a speed camera record or try and get a long jump from an elevated area. They're well marked and let you get a feel for the cars, roads and landmarks while building some currency and bonuses along the way before any real racing. Highly recommended!

The tracks and challenges vary and are always fresh-feeling. I particularly liked the 'stuntman' type series which sees you performing stunts of various types against the clock, a really nice touch and very British feeling.

TLDR? This is a great game. I'm nowhere near finishing it at 40+ hours in and from all accounts theres plenty of action yet to come... and I don't even have the DLC's or car packs. Grab it on sale, you won't regret it.

In my first impression, itâ€™s one of the best racing games I've ever played. The graphics and sound are attractive and the overall game-play of the game is well done.

I have to say that I don't really like to play racing games because of the feeling that these types of games are hard to play and I thought I had to know the different types of cars that each car would be difficult to drive but it wasn't what I thought like that. When I opened my eyes it was a game that didn't use a lot of difficult controls (I played with a keyboard) and it was very easy to understand.

Within the game's large map, there are missions, each of which includes regular racing. Missions that limit the use of cars and missions that are racing with something that it is unlikely to compete with players in various fields. It was very creative and made me prefer to find a weird car to use in the field rather than trying to get a nice one.

I came to play this game because my friend invited me to play. Another reason I decided to buy this game is because it can be played with my friends in a small party online, it's easy to create and doesn't need to load a lot of scenes while connecting. So it's recommended if you're partying with your friends who want to play games together.

If you are hesitant to play I can assure you it's worth it because besides the first play experience that made me really obsessed with this game. And yet to mention the realism of the physics or the virtual reality of the game that I might not be expert enough to say. But it made me feel that this game was really good.

Hope my review will be of some help in your decision.

I know Horizon 5 is out and soon this game will be unplayable but this game is amazing and I will always love this game for the happiness that it gave to me in a dark time in my life. Overall this game rates a 8/10 for me.

10/10 recommended.

As someone who has never been much into racing games or cars in general, I was quite surprised by how much I enjoyed my time in this game. I've had a blast exploring the open world and trying to collect and complete everything. My experience hasn't been without issues however, and there are some serious problems with this game that have put a bit of a damper on my experience.

Although I haven't had much experience playing racing games, I found the mechanics and controls to be very intuitive and after getting used to the terrible menu and extremely busy map (more on that later), I found myself enjoying driving the various vehicles almost right away. Although I was initially the most interested in collecting the hidden signs around the map and completing the various speed and distance challenges, I quickly found myself enjoying almost all the different races and challenges just as much. This game also has hundreds of different cars and has quite a bit of customization for each of them, allowing all sorts of different upgrades and paint/decals, which was a bit overwhelming at first, but was really cool to play around with once I got the hang of it. This game is also really good at giving you lots of difficulty options, so you can customize the game to be easier or harder if you'd like (for the most part). The game also looks fantastic, especially given that the game runs very well on even low end hardware (usually). I was surprised when my friend with a weaker gaming laptop had absolutely no trouble running the game.

Unfortunately, this game is not without issues, and there are some serious problems with this game that must be mentioned:
[list]
[*] This game has tons of strange bugs. The initial loading video always has the wrong resolution, the narrator is always incorrectly enabled on the starting screen, statistics often don't update properly, the way NPC vehicles drive (especially when racing online) is bizarrely jittery, inconsistent, and sometimes downright broken, navigating down in the menu sometimes doesn't work, cutscenes sometimes show the wrong car, races sometimes disappear from the map, menu items are sometimes incorrectly locked, the car often clips through the map when reloading story missions, the audio rarely slows down and becomes extremely distorted, the game sometimes softlocks when finishing a race, the game starts to slow down if you have it running for too long, it rarely doesn't save properly, and rarely the game crashes completely. Thankfully almost all of these are somewhere between uncommon and extremely rare, and most of them weren't very severe, but the sheer number of different bizarre issues I kept encountering did become annoying after a while.
[*] The menu in this game is terrible, with multiple tabs containing tiles of varying sizes, many of which are never explained, are locked without explanation, change constantly, or are duplicated on multiple pages. It is a pain to navigate, very hard to learn, and is a great example of how not to design a menu.
[*] The game is initially extremely overwhelming. The game rapidly bombards you with tons of different races and challenges when you start, many complicated screens have lots of options that are never explained, and the convoluted menu that was previously mentioned certainly doesn't help. This gives the game quite the initial learning curve which can be extremely daunting for new players.
[*] Public multiplayer matches sometimes take an extremely long time to load. I'm not sure why this is, but there are some parts of the game (such as online adventure or sandbox games) that are difficult or impossible to do because the matches either take forever to load or just never actually load (I was never patient enough to figure out which).
[*] The game shows you occasional advertisements in-game for the DLC you don't own. I never had this issue as I purchased all the DLC immediately, but this was quite annoying for my friends who didn't.
[*] Multiplayer is locked behind the completion of the initial seasons, which serves as a bit of an tutorial/introduction to the game, but is quite long, so you can't play with friends until you've played the game for a number of hours, which was a bit frustrating initially, especially since this isn't clearly indicated anywhere.
[*] The weekly weather changes are neat, but they change the road conditions pretty drastically, which makes some challenges far harder, especially in the winter season, so it is a bit frustrating to know that there are just some weeks where all your times/scores are probably going to be lower, and races/challenges are all going to be harder.
[*] There are a few parts of the game that aren't possible to complete anymore (such as the Mixer challenges or items unlocked by the discontinued Forza Hub app).
[/list]
Although I did still highly enjoy my time with this game, these issues put a bit of a damper on the experience and did cause quite a bit of frustration at some points. Thankfully I still had a good experience with this game as a whole and none of these are serious enough to prevent me from recommending this game.

[b]TL;DR[/b] This is a fantastic racing game with a great open world, good mechanics, fantastic customization, tons of content, great visuals, and good performance. Unfortunately, it is also quite overwhelming and has a wicked learning curve, and it is plagued by tons of strange bugs and bad design decision (like the terrible menu, in-game DLC advertisements, locking multiplayer behind a long introduction segment, etc.). While these issues weren't enough to keep me from having a great experience with this game, you should definitely weigh these for yourself and determine if these issues would keep you from enjoying this game or not. If you think you'd still enjoy the game despite these issues, then I'd highly recommend you pick this game up.

I've been into racing games on PS1 way back when I was a kid. Recently got back to racing games, and this is the first time in my adulthood again that I found an addicting racing game: FH4. Got it in a very cheap sale this 2022, it still holds up and there's still a lot of people to play with.

There's a shit ton of offline and online activities to do, so I don't find myself doing nothing in this game. Auction houses are a nice way also to buy and trade cars for money. You can be a buy and sell connoisseur to also earn alot of money.

This game takes up 94gb of hard disk space, but not a single megabyte of that space feels wasted. Game has tons of content to unlock, tons of locations to visit and race around in, and really accessible gameplay that can be as easy or as hard as you want it to be (PSA for casual players who prefer arcade gameplay and handling over sim: don't overtune/overupgrade your cars).

Another thing that I like about this game is that the AI doesn't cheat. There's no rubberbanding, and at the easier AI levels, you will see the CPU cars make mistakes (it's fun seeing sportscars overshoot their turns and tumble around on offroad tracks.)  So if you get good at the game, you can feel it instead of the game trying to introduce faux difficulty by giving AI cars unfair advantages.

The game location is set in the Great Britain, which the game has simulated beautifully with details. The city looks great, the countrysides, mountainsides and other landmarks look fantastic. The sound suits the game well, especially at the introduction sequence to the game. They are wide variety of car types/spec/brands (over 100 with DLCs at beginning and over 730 in total, so you will most likely find your car there). The control feel casual but not much of an arcade racing like NFS, for me it's  fun to drive and it's addictive once you master it. The game as of time of review is out of support now but they are many players in online server and there are seasonal events awaiting -- rewarding with rare/expensive cars. Only cons I found is the car sound feel a bit compressed and missing some of small detail with doesn't match its photorealistic graphic. and.. In England, We are driving on the left (like many of Asian countries) -- not a problem for me, just FYI. Recommend buying this game on discount. For full price I recommend buying its sequel -- Forza Horizon 5 since the game retaining the photorealistic graphic, superb soundtracks, significantly better engine sound, more cars and still getting updates from the developer.
