This game really has a bad sense of direction. After the first two hours you'll end up wondering what you're even supposed to do. The game gives no clues on what events you should do, how the car system works, and the story is non-existent.

[h1]Pros:[/h1]
But that's also one of the things that makes this game unique. For better or for worse. FH4 is a total sandbox where any player can do whatever they want whenever they want. You can finish the story missions or skip them entirely and start fine tuning your cars or chasing leaderboards. The difficulty can be adjusted at any time and can scale from beginner to expert. Events pop up frequently with rare rewards that give you an incentive to complete them or again, you can just skip them and focus on what you were currently doing. The game works how you want it to work. 

[h1]Cons:[/h1]
This however does have its downsides. As I mentioned, the story isn't really there at all and you'll always have to decide what you want to do as the game never guides you. The progression system is also just bad as the cars and money you'll get are totally random. Depending on your preferences you might hate this game or love it. Still, Forza Horizon 4 is a seriously well crafted game and still has hours of content to complete and thousands of active players even after so many years from its initial release.

[h1]Forza Horizon 5:[/h1]
However, [b]do not[/b] get this game if you haven't yet played Forza Horizon 5. FH5 is the sequel to this game and has so much more new content, improvements, a better story and a level of graphics and immersion that makes FH4 look like it was from two generations ago. FH4 is still a worthwhile game to get but only do it if you have already bought FH5 and want even more Forza. Also, in some regions this game is way too overpriced so you might want to avoid it and just get FH5 instead.

A pretty dope game, I love the graphics, the physics and the car roster. Customisation is a bit limited, but it more than makes up for it with the sheer amount of stuff you can do in the world.

It's like the Crew 2 with better graphics, more realistic driving, and then worse everything else. 

The menus are cumbersome, it takes forever to do anything, the load times are frequent and long, the effort that goes into getting into a multiplayer group is way too much.

Here's an example of an experience I had last night: Invite friend to group > they can join group but not my game > Game tells me to join them instead > Reform group with me joining them > Load into their session > Drive to a race to do together > Our seasons are desynced for some reason, have to wait for my season to change > Get into race > Race last 3 minutes > Wait for my season to change back > Repeat for next race.  

After managing to even get into the same lobby, it's about 10 minutes worth of work and load screens to do a 3 minute race, just to repeat it after. 

Also worth pointing out, I'm on a very high end system, so I don't think this is based on my pc, the game is just cumbersome. 

There are also a lot of times where the NPCs force your map open, and just won't shut up, and your just sitting there waiting to be allowed to go back to doing whatever you were doing before.

The game also throws free cars at you to the point that you never really feel like you have to work for anything. 5 hours in, and my car collection is already massive, beyond just what the DLC gives you. The amount of cars you get from wheel spins in crazy. The same goes for the games currency, you make more from wheel spins than you do playing the actual game.
This was all pretty disappointing, because I picked this up wanting another open world racing game to play, and thought this looked amazing. I hope they can clean some of this stuff up for Horizon 5.

This game definitely has some really strong points to, but overall didn't add enough to make me have a good time. 

Some things I really liked about the game were: The car tuning system. Being able to custom tweak your car to get exactly the performance you want, or being able to import other peoples tunings if you don't want to learn how to do it yourself is an amazing idea. Some cars that are cool to look at but generally would under perform can be made into absolute monsters with this system. 

The Name system where you can pick your name and have the NPC's use it in dialogue or on your GPS was a nice touch I really liked.

The amount of cosmetics for your avatar where awesome, though I wish there were more faces/hairstyles for them because they look jank.

The game is visually stunning. I prefer the Crew 2 over this game by a mile, and think the Crew 2 looks great, but this game is just unbelievable visually. 

Having houses you can buy and travel to is a neat concept, but without being able to walk around them or have cars displayed, it really just feels like a way for them to force you to drive somewhere to access certain menus as opposed to a cool feature.

I also wish the weather progressed faster, the seasons system is a cool concept, but if you end up hating one of the seasons, having to play on it for a week at a time is rough.

I also feel like the map is very small. For an open world game, there really isn't much diversity, and you can get across the map pretty quickly.

I don't mean to sound like a hater, because I really want to love this game, it just makes it really hard. I'll definitely be picking up Horizon 5 in hopes that they've improved on a lot of things, but I don't think there's any reason to pick this one up.

The mixture of sim to arcade definitely skews to the arcade side, but that doesn't take away at all from what is, essentially, an absolute blast of a driving game. It's so much fun to hop in the wheeled-vehicle of your choice and just drive around the beautiful and meticulously detailed open world in the British countryside. I tried Motorsport for comparison, and while I could appreciate its more raw, accurate, and intense simulator nature, I just didn't have as much fun playing it. I never thought a driving game would hold my attention for this long, but here I am, close to the 40 hour mark, and still not sure when I'll be able to put this down. Awesome game.

The Good:
The core gameplay (driving) is good. It can be customized to be more arcade-like or more sim-like, depending on what you want. There are more arcade-like games out there (e.g. Need for Speed series) and there are more sim-like games (Assetto Corsa) but this game hits the perfect balance of both. Like if you only had space for 1 racing game in your library, this is a good choice.

The game support Ultra Widescreen resolutions quite well, but you can tell it didn't start out that way and Ultra Widescreen support was just added along the way. The splash, intro and cut scenes are not in ultrawide. But all the core gameplay modes support ultrawide and the game looks great in it.
It makes me want to invest in a racing wheel and building my own racing cockpit for the sim-like experience, but unfortunately there's not enough space in our house for a setup like that. But that's an option for people to get a more realistic "driving sim" experience. It'll be a safe environment for the wife to practice driving ğŸ™‚.

The sceneries are gorgeous. In between intense racing, you could just sort of drive around, admiring the views. There are many moments where I'm driving to my next mission, but there's a vista or beauty spot I happen to pass through (driving along a beach, or a waterfall) and I have to stop to take a few pictures. It's a nice change of pace from all the breakneck racing. This is what separates it from all the other racing games out there, IMO. It has a photography mini-game.

Speaking of mini-games, there are lots of options to earn money in the game aside from winning races. I created a design for my own cars and made it public. A few days later, I was pleasantly surprised to find "Design Reward" messages in my inbox saying I earned 100 credits for each time my design was downloaded and used by other players. There's also a taxi business I invested 100,00 credits into, and it's slowly earning back the in-game credits I invested. There's also an auction house for cars, but the implementation is better than it was in Diablo 3, in that it wasn't short-circuiting player progression. Cars are so easy to acquire, there's no real need to go to the auction house unless it's for a particular rare car you're looking for.ğŸ™‚
Drew and I bought this game to get a preview of what Forza 5 Horizons might look like, and so far I'm not disappointed.

The Bad:
The UI is a bit cluttered. It took me some time to get used to it. I thought there was no quick way to go to your garage to customize a car you just bought, but it was just hidden in one of the tabs. There are fast travel options to some destinations, but not all. When completing races, new destinations will pop up on the world map, and over time this WILL make the world map super cluttered.
The not-so-bad:
Car acquisition and collection is easy.
Car customization is not as extensive as in Need for Speed Underground. You can only paint the body, hood, side mirrors, spoiler and tint the windows. So far I haven't seen an option to purchase body kits, unless it already came with the car.
Car upgrading and tuning is not as extensive as Gran Turismo 2, but it comes close. You can adjust gear ratios to balance acceleration vs top speed. I haven't dived too deeply into it, but there are options to tune the tires, alignment, antiroll bars, springs, damping, aero, brakes and differential.
If you stop a multi-race session (e.g. a story mission that has 10 races), there's no easy way to just pick up from where you left off. The game will drop you off in your Home starting point, and you have to drive all the way to where you picked up the mission to resume it.
There's no unified, cohesive storyline. Just chapters that pop up all over the place ğŸ˜ƒ.
This being a game released in 2018, there's a lot of content to grind through, and someone new to the game will feel a bit overwhelmed by all the content.

The Ugly:
Online Multiplayer with friends.
Oh my God, Drew and I had such a hard time setting up a convoy so we can drive around and race together. I think it's because the network architecture is housed by Xbox, and we're playing on the Steam platform.

This game is one of the most fun racers Iâ€™ve played in years. [b](Skip to the TLDR if you want to skip the personal stuff.)[/b]

Itâ€™s kinda funny though, since my history with the Forza Horizon series is a bit more complicated than that. I played and loved the first game when it came out, mostly enjoyed the second (even though I admittedly played the much weaker Xbox 360 version) and absolutely loathed Forza Horizon 3. I donâ€™t know what exactly it was about that one that drove me crazy. Was it the characters that wouldnâ€™t stop nagging you about activities you should be doing? Probably. Maybe it was the map that felt more like a diorama rather than a real place. Perhaps it was the horrible PC port performance, or the experience that was trying to download it through Microsoftâ€™s store front, only for the download to fail and you had to redownload all that data all over again. The more I think about it, it was probably all of those things combined, a perfect storm that pushed me to just uninstall it shortly after Blizzard Mountain came out. I remember telling myself that the only way I would ever try Forza Horizon again was if it came to Steam. At the time, I figured that was a pipe dream, but Iâ€™m glad I was wrong.

The thing is, Forza Horizon 4 is itself pretty similar to Forza Horizon 3, in terms of structure at least. Where Horizon 3 pushed the series away from having a linear story and more towards being a sandbox of sorts, Horizon 4 takes that and refines it to a near perfect sheen that then inches itself a bit closer to turning this series into a AAA budget Test Drive Unlimited successor, complete with houses you can buy and drivers you can play dress up with. Some would say theyâ€™re pointless additions, but Iâ€™ve had way more fun dressing my driver up to be ridiculously flashy and pairing that up with crazy looking cars than I initially thought possible. Itâ€™s a fun little â€œlife sim-liteâ€ touch that you donâ€™t even really have to engage with if you donâ€™t want to; just put on a helmet and racing suit when you get them and be on your way. That being said, the houses are really just glorified fast travel points here, so Iâ€™d love to see them fleshed out more in a future game, especially since the rest of the game is practically flawless.

As for the core racing and driving gameplay itself? Yes, you still get nagged about new races, PR stunts, and other activities, but only for the first time they appear; from then on, the game just lets you do what you want and have fun. I know some people think the map is too samey and bland, but personally I love it; it feels like a smaller, more local stop on a bigger, grander tour. For me, itâ€™s been such a delight cruising around, especially as the seasons change, that itâ€™s made me look forward to Forza Horizon 5 that much more, to see how it fits a more diverse map into this super solid formula. Of course Steam, in terms of being a game download client, is miles ahead of the Windows Store. However, this version did have some very weird performance problems at launch; constant micro-stuttering, some annoying crashes out of the blue. As of a few months ago though, itâ€™s felt rock solid to me, but YMMV.

I mentioned earlier that Forza Horizon is more of a sandbox these days, but I had no idea it would be this addicting all these years later. Thatâ€™s part of why Iâ€™m finally getting around to writing a review after over 300 hours played since its Steam release; because as much as there are other games I could be playing, I still find myself looking at the Festival Playlist each week and thinking to myself, â€œYeah, why not do another Trial championship for a truck I already have? I could just sell it later.â€ Thatâ€™s just how fun the driving is in this game, that I want to keep playing it, unlike the previous game in the series that I had to force myself to push on instead.

[b]TLDR:[/b] Believe the hype. Forza Horizon 4 is one of the best racing games on PC, period. The driving is sublime, thereâ€™s tons of cars to collect and customize to your heartâ€™s content, and the game has so many different ways of driving and racing around (road, dirt, street scene, cross country, Super7 community challenges, that battle royale mode â€œThe Eliminatorâ€ that is way more fun than you would think) that this really is a nearly perfect racing paradise. Even with Forza Horizon 5 around the corner, thereâ€™s still so much here to play with and enjoy, even if you just pick it up for the time being until the new one comes out, that I could never not recommend it.

Best Car game in the world, hands down.

I grew up with a brother that loved the Forza Motorsports games (we had FM2 for our Xbox) but I thought it was very boring. Cars and tuning have been a bit of an obsession over the last couple years but I don't have my own project car or performance machine yet. Instead of beating too hard on my little Chev Sonic I decided to pull the trigger on Horizon 4 and it was a fantastic idea! It checks almost all the boxes for me. It's a gorgeous game, the seasonal changes are beautiful, there's more cars than I could have imagined, and there is loads of content. I have no doubt that driving a FH4 car is leaps and bounds different than driving the same car IRL -- even with a gaming wheel, pedal set, and shifter -- but it's very fun to imagine it so.

There are a couple of personal gripes. I feel like accumulating credits is a little too easy, as is adding loads of power to a basic car. After your first 8-10 races, you could buy a 4-banger with 120hp and load it up with a racing V8, twin turbos, AWD, and racing slicks bringing it from a low B class to a high S1 class. Personally, I have been playing with my own sets of "project car" rules: buy a classic project car (240sx, Civic, Miata, Mustang, GTI, etc) and give it a shoddy paint job with rust spots and mismatched panels, plus a couple little mods like intake and ignition. Every race you win grants you money to spend on it: 5,000 for 1st, 3,000 for 2nd, and 1,000 for first. Placing 10th, 11th, and 12th makes you lose 1,000, 2,000, and 3,000 respectively. Paint jobs cost 10,000 and drivetrain/engine swaps cost 25,000 regardless of what it is. Everything else is fair game. It makes me feel more like I'm rowing through the advancements of upgrades, closer to what owning a project race car might be like. Again, it's fun to imagine!

Another issue I have is how the map is set. The content in plentiful, but convoluted and distracting. Every race you win gives you three more in its category. After winning three or four in each category the map is chock full of "NEW" badges, not to mention all of the "beauty spots", "influencer boards", and "fast travel boards", PLUS the "danger signs", "speed traps", and "drift zones". I understand you can filter out any unwanted categories for the map but I believe most of those should be off as default.

I, again, praise this game again. I built my PC four years ago with definitely not top-of-the-line parts but it continues to run this game beautifully, even with Spotify playing and Chrome in the background. The music choices in the built-in radio are awesome (plus featuring my favorite local rap collective, Shredders! Shoutout to my MPLS folks). The seasonal challenges are widely varied and exciting. I simply love it.

I expect to be buying FH5, though not in the first 6-12 months of its release. I still have much to explore :)

EDIT: I would like to add BUY A CONTROLLER. I tried with keyboard/mouse and it kind of ruined my first few hours of play time. FH4 tried to make it work but it's just not enjoyable. I bought a "Forty4 Wireless Gaming Controller" on Amazon for $37 and it made a world of difference.

Well, now, after 300 hours, I can truly say "This game is amazing!". This is literally the best arcade racing game ever: a hell of a lot of cars (you definitely will never drive all of them), handful amount of tracks, stories and a bunch of different activities throughout the map. Oh, and goddamn police is nowhere is sight! As well as there is no "Fast and furious" level plot no one asked for (seriously, thank god there is no story, just an idea of festival and no more).

Britain in game isn't quite accurate but looks gorgeous nonetheless. Graphics are simply astonishing and produce magnificent screenshots.

Radio stations provide some quality music, but for three hundred hours they have too few tracks. And DJs are funny enough too. 

If you're hungry for more races, there are weekly seasonal events. It's a good opportunity to win some rare and hard to find cars. Even I of all people, who hate daily/weekly/whatever repeatable activities, enjoy seasonal championships. They force you to explore your garage and choose cars that you'll never drive otherwise.

On the other hand we have Horizon Life server, Online Adventures and Playgrounds. The server isn't stable, game often loses connection with it, loading between two online races in Adventures or Playgrounds may take an eternity. And on top of that Online races are flooded with rammers, "meta cars" and douchebags.

The UX. Oh the horrible UX. There are so many hoops you have to jump through to get to stuff. I'm all for for some healthy grind to unlock better cars, cosmetics, etc. But boy, why do I have to travel to every event through the map even when I want to race with my friends online?! The fast travel feature is just unreachable. The unskippable cut-scenes. The disconnecting from your online session when an even starts with granting you a choice of a free car. The list can go on. And it's not like the content isn't there so the developers had to stretch the game out with all these unskippable chores. The content IS there. Why in the name of all that is holy did they do this to their players... At this point it feels like the devs were absolutely sure they no better than the players what the fun is. Or they were way to proud with every single feature of the game that they just felt you had to pay to skip them. With in-game currency or your time.

First of all, it's controller oriented. On the wheel you should watch a video about the exact recommended settings, but even then it won't feel as good as beamng, assetto corsa or other driving games. The Force Feedback is also really bad in my case, because instead of trying to bring the wheel to the center the game wants the wheel to go to the side, I fixed it via Thrustmaster Control Panel, letting the wheel decide the FFB, instead of the game. It's still enjoyable with steering wheel but it really is more fun with a controller.
If you are on controller however, I definitely recommend this game (I still do with a wheel but you might encounter these problems).
The game has visually stunning graphics, good physics for an "Arcade" driving game and a vast, long gameplay. It is fun trying to get all the nice cars, having a wheelspin every level-up and just all-in-all driving. There are many races available (rally, street etc) and other story oriented stuff which give you money, it's really fun, would definitely recommend.

Don't think of getting this game here if you have an existing account from, say, getting free Xbox Game Pass time from Discord. It can't carry over your progress due to "technical limitations" just buy it in the Microsoft Store.

1) First of all, your user's folder and actually all other directory names in the path to the game must be in Latin characters. It took me several hours to find it out. If you change or create a new user, you MUST delete the game and install it again.
2) Game is incredible, and you can play it on a decent PC build. But if you have good specs, you'll be amazed at how good and natural it looks. Controls and difficulty level are easy enough to spend half an hour every evening and don't get stack.
3) The game is definitely worth the money, even at full price.

I love cars. And naturally after watching tons of videos on YouTube showing driving in Forza Horizon 4 I decided to get this game. I don't even know where to start. Anyway. 1) You can't turn off the stupid voice over, you can turn it down to 1. And whenever the voice starts even when it is on the lowest volume everything else is sort of muted to a point where you can't even hear the engine properly. And if you're driving manual that is irritating. 2) The engine sounds are horrible. More about this later. 3) Online. It's a very intense moment between you and a Ferrari. The finish line is getting closer but you were racing each other side by side the entire time. You're approaching to the final corner when all of a sudden the game freezes... So you have to open the task manager and end the process because obviously nothing else works. There have been lots of crashes lately. 4) The tuning. It doesn't make any sense at all. So, let's say, you like an X car and you spend hour after hour making it better. Making it as good as possible. The best in A class. You fine tune everything that's possible. And finally you are ready to race it. But wait! What's happened? An Atomic Punk(whatever that is) just beat you? OK, Maybe it was a very experienced player. Let's try again. WHAT?! Again? Beaten by 2 Atomic Punks that came first and second. It's useless... There are only one or two cars in a certain class that can win online. The rest of 500 or so cars aren't simply fast enough. 5) Tuning 2.0. You can make any car 4wd which is obviously required otherwise you won't win any race. You can put the same v8 or v12 or any other engine in every car so naturally they will all sound the same - horrible. 6) Clothing. I know in this day and age it's very tolerant to put short skirts on men but this is a racing game, a car game. I don't need a million types of clothing(which are actually the same things only with different colors) especially when I'm not even going to walk my character. What's the point? Really? The only good outfit is The Stig's outfit. That's it! I mean you can be The Stig for crying out loud. 7) It's too generous. When I first started playing and the game made me choose one of the three cars for the rest of the career (at least I thought that way) I was thinking for a long time before I made a choice. And after 1 hour or so I have a Bugatti. And then a McLaren. And then 400000. At no point during my playtime did I think "oh, I need money for that". You're a millionaire from the start. *) There is so much more that I haven't included that make no sense whatsoever and will eventually drive you crazy. Conclusion) Don't buy this at this price point. Only during a big sale. I MEAN IT! Only during a sale.

Building upon everything that has continued to mark out the Forza Horizon series as something special and unique its own right - beyond being Forza Motorsport's carefree sibling - Forza Horizon 4 demonstrates once again just how recklessly entertaining driving roughshod across an open environment can be. I love this game, and had hundreds more hours on the Xbox. All in all, I would give this game a 8/10. There is an insane amount of cars to collect and tune however you want. The world is pretty, although it'll feel very samey after a while and there is no dedicated race track (wtf). 

I really like this game, but here are the things I dislike:

- Engine noises are awful. Like, really awful. Any X class car (basically super cars) sounds like a rattling tin can.
- No sense of progression. Unlike games like Need for Speed, you don't really have to work for a really good car. You're given cars like candy, especially this far into the game's lifecycle with all the bonus wheelspins, and I got 1 million credits right of the bat from spins. Personally, I just like collecting cars so this isn't an issue for me, but many people won't like it.
- A ton of cool cars are locked behind wheelspins, essentially free lootboxes. If you want a car really bad and it's behind a wheelspin just look at the auction house. The RNG gods are never kind. Again, wheelspins are free and cannot be bought (good).
The Photo mode it's better than the gameplay itself, love it so much!
this game makes me smile and brain go weee
this is the best game i everplay in racing CAR.

I really like Forza Horizon 4. It's not as realistic as other racing sims out there but I like the arcade part. I like upgrading my cars up to the limit allowed and tweaking it to just get that slight edge that makes you win the race.

The map is pretty big and it's fun to explore new areas. You'll see most of the map if you do all races and stories. 

Apart from racing there's also other game modes where you can play battle royale, infection, capture the flag and other style games with other players.

Most of the story missions are alright but some are just annoying but thankfully just have to be done once and they give decent rewards when completed.

There are also a few annoyances about FH4: once in a while you'll have to restart the game because some mechanics stop working (like rewind will suddenly stop working in the middle of a race or even in free roam), online session will not be able to connect, online (ranked) matchmaking can sometimes take ages to find players, especially ranked can sometimes take like 20-30 minutes if you're unlucky. 

Many cheaters/modders/hackers ruin the gameplay by getting impossible results in races/speedtraps/etc leaderboards. It's been like this for ever and nothing is being done to remove the clearly cheated numbers like driving 9.000 km/h through a speedtrap or finish a 6 km race in 0.05 seconds. I wish these people would get banned/accounts deleted and their entries removed from the leaderboards. It's been a long-term complaint from the community but it's very obvious the developers couldn't care less because they have never bothered to fix or do anything about it.

Also the winter season sucks, don't bother doing storyline or regular races in winter because you'll have to adapt to the snow but still be expected to perform equally as if the road isn't a big ice rink. 

I would recommend getting FH4 on sale or get the game + DLC pack when it's on discount, which really increases the value because the DLCs can get a bit expensive when they are added up.
If you enjoy arcade style racing sims, this one is really a recommendation.

Buy if cheap, but not the best racing game out there.  Great graphics, car sound is ok, plenty to do, but completely unrealistic.  I mean, I was doing 200 MPH in a Pagani Zonda through the English country side flying over hills, taking out trees, stone walls, and steel barriers with ease.

This is an arcade style game mixed with tuning that can be mostly ignored.  Cars are thrown at you in this game, so there is nothing to really work for except achievements.

I was in the Zonda accelerating like a bat out of hell and some mustang just kept pulling away from me at a higher top speed.  Totally unrealistic game when it comes to driving, but it looks amazing.  Plenty of things to do for sure.  Need For Speed Shift was a far more realistic driving game that wasn't a simulator like Project Cars.

Great game. Unlike horizon 3, this one is super optimized for PC. Everything is faster, from fps to loading to... cars too for some reason. Expect Forza quality races, but with a arcade twist. 

THIS IS NOT A RACE SIMULATION GAME.

I am running an old 1070 graphics card and I am constantly getting between 60 to 75 frames. It is super smooth, the cars are beautiful, you can customize your car into whatever you want mechanically (awd to rwd or the reverse, change a L2 to V8, etc). 

You can even customize your own avatar into the douche that you probably are.

One point taken for not be able to change seasons on the fly. You have to wait a week for the next season rotate. I don't understand this, why did they make it this way? I have to wait 2 weeks to drive in snow seriously?!?

Warning: If you want to continue liking this game don't join random online lobbies.

Forza Horizon 4 is a greatest driving game i ever seen to date. It has a ton of irl cars and also the option to tune them to your liking. It's also possible to play alone with no other people and race against "drivatar" AI of chosen difficuilty with harder AI giving you more currency.
There are also options to enable some assists that also increase the amount of currency you earn.
The only problem i have with the game is that at least for a person who doesn't enjoy multiplayer that much earning money is kinda painfull even with the VIP bonus, which gets very annoying if you want some car that is "hard to find" aka you will probably need to buy it from other players and there is a great chance that the people will sell it only for the maximum price possible which may be 20 million, like its for the car i personally want.

But i still would recommend this game for anyone who wan't an actual driving game to drive around and race in because most other games are really outmatched a lot by forza.

It's the perfect Forza game for every type of racing fan. You can make it as easy or as difficult as you want and there are a ton of cars on the roster. My favorite thing is the sense of progression that was missing from previous Forza games when they were almost entirely DLC based. You get cars as you level up and you have an incentive to do all the content for all of the rewards. 

I love the gameplay style of Forza, and this is the best iteration of the series.
Must buy if you're into cars. That's it.

[b]UPDATE:[/b] 
So I've changed my review to "Not Recommended". The game itself is solid and the good parts are still good. But for reasons unknown to man they keep "updating" this game despite it being in maintenance mode and pretty much every update breaks something. As of December 2022 the game constantly freezes up and/or crashes on Nvidia GPUs (and apparently some AMD GPUs too). No fix in sight. All the devs have to say is to rollback your drivers for one, now outdated game.

[b]ORIGINAL REVIEW:[/b]
Excellent open world arcade/sim-cade racer. Best in class really. Ridiculous amount of cars to unlock. Tons and tons of activities to sink your teeth into. If you like cars and you like clearing open world maps you'll like this. Performance is also solid, the game looks and runs fantastic. 

The only real gripe is online play can be buggy. Sometimes you'll get stuck in a loading screen for several minutes and other times it just straight up gets stuck in a infinite loading screen with the only way out being to force close the game.

DON'T BUY ON STEAM if you want to connect a wheel AND shifter (and handbrake, etc). The fact that the microsoft store version of this game has been patched to remedy the INEXPLICABLE inability for this game to accept multiple usb devices for input, while the steam version has been left dead in the water is frankly unacceptable. tbh i want my money back so i can buy the microsoft store version instead. that said, here's my review:

I delayed playing Forza Horizon 4 because I thought it wouldn't be enough of a "sim." I totally regret it. This game is not a sim, but it's a massive blast. When I turn off all the assists, there's enough physics and force feedback fidelity to feel satisfyingly "simmy" and the arcade elements ensure that it never gets boring and mundane. The season progression is a genius idea and I can't stop thinking of the next car/upgrade I want or what fantastic terrain I want to test it on. There's an element of creativity to the car tunings that lets you experiment and discover cars that are truly "yours," or you can play the game without touching the car setups at all and just use other players' magic. There's a ton of freedom in this open-world driver and just enough direction to have you sprinting from one event to the next. One of my all time favorites.

TLDR really good game, and I wholeheartedly like it. I reccomend it if you dont have a strong setup but still want to drive around. But :

If I could give this a neutral, I would. So this review is gonna be extremely biased and might only affect me and I'll keep it short.

Pros :
- Physics are obviously arcadey but realistic enough.
- costumization could be as simple as counting 1 to 5 or could be quite in depth
- car models and performances are terrific
- going out on a ride with your buddies or just speeding in the highway at night alone is pretty nice
- you can either make a beast of a car or tune it to be an absolute meme, outspeeding hypercars in a honda with a v12 or something
- making 60km long trial races are fun
- mix of environments are a big plus

Cons (heres the very biased part)
- sucks that you cant disable winter season, though it diversifies things which is good, I still hate how they take away my ability to drift or grip on most of the roads i drive for a week.
- alot of engine sounds are inaccurate, the Dodge Viper sounds especially atrocious.
- people are mostly meta slaves driving awd hypercars going 400+kmh
- game runs like a massive trash on fire after getting pissed by a dog
- if your game for some damned reason freezes for a MILISECOND, you WILL be disconnected no matter what
- if you alt tab after the game runs after a while, your computer will stutter horribly, resulting to the previous point above
- matchmaking can take more than 5 minutes just to get you into the session
- matchmaking can also kill itself, letting the rest of your friends in a convoy join a session and leave you behind
- they dont do reruns of events rewarding extremely rare vehicles, i.e the Toyota 1no AE86, Ferrari 599XX Evo (metaslave trash), Toyota GT86, etc. selling for extremely high prices as well.
- optimization is trash
- Forza Horizon 5 is coming

Again, I really like this game, its ability to give you alot of things to do, its low system requirement, its ease to get into, its friendliness to beginners on Keyboards. 
If youre still thinking of getting this game and youve got a low(er) spec PC, go for it.

I will start off with an info that I love this game and so I recommend it to anyone who seeks some action and cool driving mechanics.

I've been playing on game pad so far and I must admit that the further into the game (I play on pretty realistic settings with any helpers off) the more game punishes you for not having steering wheel or pedals.

If you don't want to lose your freaking mind then I suggest not playing for 3 stars in every story event with same setup as mine.
Of course I've been annoyed by random AI on the road during some of the events because to get 3 stars in some you need be pretty accurate and the worst feeling ever to be at the highest speed possible, getting into the curve just right, and meeting the front of the AI car.. xD

I haven't played multiplayer because I'm old-style solo car games kind of guy. And I'm enjoying it a lot.
..but it seems to be pretty multiplayer oriented anyway so don't get your hopes up. There is no story line if you expected one.

I feel this game also suffers from some kind of off-road mainstream as the normal racing is basically limited to one events chain whereas off-road is basically main thing for everything. There still are some cool streets to race though, so that's okay.

Skills system is f-ing bad. I mean it's not satisfying, getting points and streaks means nothing to me. I feel almost insulted by how the system works. No, drifting is apparently not the way to go, just f-ing smash things around, jump couple of times, smash things, do a 180 and repeat. Also have I mentioned smashing things is important?

Overall I believe the game is nice, there are a lot of cars and a lot of fun, but I see significant flaws in game systems and also - which because of the scale of the game is quite obvious - level design on a lot of races. There are community ones so that's sorting this issue out a bit.

Buy on a special price. Not full. Especially now that there is Forza Horizon 5 on the way :)
